title: Liquid
description: The melting point of pure iron is 1538°C. The eutectic point temperature at around 4.3wt% carbon is 1147°C. Cast irons with carbon content above 4.3wt% are called hypereutectic, whereas cast irons with 2.11-4.3wt% carbon are called hypoeutectic.

title: Ferrite
description: Below 912°C, iron has a BCC crystal structure. The ferrite phase (α-Fe) is fairly ductile, and magnetic.

title: Delta
description: Above 1394°C, iron changes back to a BCC phase: delta iron (δ-Fe).

title: Pearlite + Ferrite
description: Pearlite has a characterisitc lamellar structure made of alternating layers of ferrite and cementite. It forms during slow cooling of the alloy through the eutectoid reaction occuring below 723 °C.

title: Pearlite + Cementite
description: White cast irons are generally hard and brittle due to the presence of cementite, and have excellent flowability.

title: Liquid + Cementite
description: Cementite (Fe<sub>3</sub>C) precipitates from the liquid upon cooling.

title: Liquid + Austenite
description: Austenite (γ-Fe) precipitates from the liquid upon cooling.

title: Delta + Liquid
description: Delta (δ-Fe) precipitates from the liquid upon cooling.

title: Cementite + Ledeburite
description: Cementite (Fe<sub>3</sub>C) is an iron carbide with orthorombic crystal structure. It is hard, brittle, and ferromagnetic. It is also metastable; under very slow cooling, or by maintaining the alloy above 723°C during a heat treatment, cementite can decompose into ferrite and graphite.

title: Austenite + Cementite + Ledeburite
description: Ledeburite is the eutectic phase of iron forming at 4.3wt% of carbon. It may occur as a separate constituent in high-carbon steels.

title: Cementite + Pearlite + Ledeburite
description: In gray cast irons, carbon is found in the form of graphite - which gives the material a characteristic gray colour.

title: Austenite
description: Austenite (γ-Fe) exists above the critical eutectoid temperature of 727°C. It is non-magnetic, with an FCC crystal structure. Adding nickel to steel, in particular, stabilizes austenite so that it can be used at room temperature, for example in stainless steel.
